results.title: The ABC of unions
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A group of high school students, reacting against their harsh music master, devise an analogous story about why there are trade unions. They learn all about arbitration, bargaining and compromise. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: New sound of music
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This BBC documentary narrated and presented by Michael Rodd demonstrates a sample of technology and technique musicians and sound recordists have used to come up with a “new sound in music”. The use of early oscillation and voltage control sound effects, computers, music synthesisers, multi-track-recording techniques, including tape manipulation are shown. Some early-automated musical instruments such as the Pianola and a programmed mechanical robotic violin are also seen. The presenter demonstrates how the electronic music theme to “Dr Who” was created in the BBC’s Radiophonic Workshop and other musical themes for television are shown in their creation. Archival footage showing a stage performance of an unattended computer that can make unique musical composition choices is included along with its inventor Peter Zinovieff (the founder of EMS: Electronic Music Studios) at home in his studio. Musician and inventor David Voorhaus demonstrates the “Maniac”, a unique analogue sequencer and an instrument that uses magnetic tape in the place of strings he created.

results.title: Speech and language disorders
results.creator_credit: Queensland. Dept. of Education. Media Services
results.brief_description: A comprehensive introduction to the work of speech therapists. Looks at speech and language disorders in children, such as, poor communication and stuttering; and the problems adults face after strokes and throat cancers. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: At 'Edge' with Judith Wright
results.creator_credit: Solrun Hoaas and Sync or Swim Documentaries
results.brief_description: A study of Judith Wright, her poetry and her links with the Australian landscape - in particular her relation to her property of “Edge” in Mangarlowe, N.S.W. Filmed at “Edge” in the Half-moon Wildlife District and featuring Roger Pulvers as the interviewer. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: The Changing world of Charles Dickens
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Jonathan Hansen, Allan King and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Recreates scenes from “David Copperfield”, “Oliver Twist”, “Dombey and Son”, “Great Expectations” and “Hard Times” in order to illustrate how Dickens not only reflected the harshness of his times but sought to change the social inequities as well. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Does anybody need me anymore?
results.creator_credit: Paul Bogart and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Part of the “Being a woman” series. Observes the changes which occur in the marriage of a middle-aged couple when the wife decides to change her own lifestyle after her children are grown and gone. Raises issues regarding women’s roles, sex-role stereotyping, changing expectaions of the female role and the male perception of such topics.
